[00:03.00]Passage Three
[00:04.72]The period of engagement is the time
[00:06.87]between the marriage proposal and the wedding ceremony.
[00:11.29]Two people agree to marry
[00:14.00]when they decide to spend their lives together.
[00:17.51]The man usually gives the woman a diamond engagement ring.
[00:22.81]That tradition is said to have started
[00:25.93]when an Austrian man gave a diamond ring to the woman he wanted to marry.
[00:31.94]The diamond represented beauty.
[00:35.25]He placed it on the third finger of her left hand.
[00:39.36]He chose that finger because it was thought
[00:42.00]that the blood vessel in that finger went directly to the heart.
[00:47.31]Today we know that this is not true,
[00:50.62]yet the tradition continues.
[00:53.77]Americans generally are engaged for a period of about one year
[00:58.00]if they are planning a wedding ceremony and a party.
[01:00.95]During this time,
[01:02.78]friends of the bride may hold a party at which women friends
[01:06.29]and family members give the bride gifts that she will need as a wife.
[01:11.10]These could include cooking equipment or new clothing.
[01:17.18]Friends of the man who is getting married may have a bachelor party for him.
[01:21.73]This usually takes place the night before the wedding.
[01:25.59]Only men are invited to the bachelor party.
[01:29.61]During the marriage ceremony,
[01:31.60]the bride and her would-be husband usually exchange gold rings
[01:37.56]that represent the idea that their union will continue forever.
[01:42.01]The wife often wears both the wedding ring
[01:44.93]and the engagement ring on the same finger.
[01:47.85]The husband wears his ring on the third finger of his left hand.
[01:52.20]Many people say the purpose of the engagement period
[01:55.94]is to permit enough time to plan the wedding.
[01:58.94]But the main purpose is to let enough time pass,
[02:02.66]so the two people are sure they want to marry each other
[02:06.35]Either person may decide to break the engagement,
[02:10.37]if this happens,
[02:12.06]the woman usually returns the ring to the man.
[02:15.79]They also return any wedding gifts they have received.

[01:38.94]The graduates of these courses often start out in middle management jobs.

[00:03.45]When my interest shifted from space to the sea,
[00:07.21]I never expected it would cause such confusion among my friends.
[00:12.21]Yet I can understand their feelings.
[00:15.30]As I have been writing and talking about space flight for the best part of 20 years,
[00:21.22]a sudden switch of interest to the depth of the sea does seem peculiar.
[00:26.48]To explain,I'd like to share my reasons behind this unusual change of mind.
[00:31.96]The first excuse I give is an economic one.
[00:35.19]Underwater exploration is so much cheaper than space flight.
[00:40.08]The first round-trip ticket to the moon is going to cost at least 10 billion dollars if you include research and development.
[00:48.88]By the end of this century, the cost will be down to a few million.
[00:53.62]On the other hand, the diving suit and a set of basic tools needed for skin-diving can be bought for 20 dollars.
[01:01.35]My second argument is more philosophical.
[01:04.48]The ocean, surprisingly enough, has many things in common with space.
[01:09.20]In their different ways, both sea and space are equally hostile.
[01:14.83]If we wish to survive in either for any length of time, we need to have mechanical aids
[01:21.42]The diving suit helped the design of the space suit.
[01:25.98]The feelings and the emotions of a man beneath the sea will be much like those of a man beyond the atmosphere.

[00:01.54]Section C
[00:05.24]Americans are suffering from a serious problem of sleeping less.
[00:10.29]They also cut back on leisure activities as they spend more time at work.
[00:14.72]A world that “never goes to sleep” offers many diverse activities,
[00:19.99]but encourages unhealthy and sometimes anti-social lifestyles for America's adults.
[00:26.03]Instead of working to live, they are living to work,
[00:29.46]a shift that has had a deep impact on their personal lives.
[00:33.30]Adults report spending less time sleeping but more engaging in social and leisure activities.
[00:39.64]Most Americans admit they suffer from sleep problems and when they go to sleep,
[00:44.78]many sleep alone even if they are married.
[00:47.93]These are the key findings in the National Sleep Foundation's 2001“Sleep in America” poll,
[00:54.35]which looks at the relationship between American's lifestyles, sleep habits and sleep problems.
[01:00.86]Loss of sleep continues to be widespread in America. According to the poll,
[01:06.20]63% of American adults do not get the recommended eight hours of sleep needed for good health, safety, and most favorable performance.
[01:16.47]In fact, nearly 1/3 report sleeping less than seven hours each weeknight,
[01:21.54]though many adults say they try to sleep more on weekends.
[01:25.39]The poll shows both good news and bad news.
[01:28.68]The good news is that many Americans say they don't want to give up any more sleep in spite of their exciting lives.
[01:35.42]And they would sleep more if they were convinced it would contribute to their quality of life.
[01:40.34]The bad news is far too many adults still sacrifice sleep, which is an unhealthy way of life.
[01:47.78]Perhaps further study should be made to help them get rid of the terrible lifestyle.

[07:53.65]of the purpose early in the message.

[08:00.24]keep paragraphs short,
[08:01.55]much like newspaper articles.

[08:10.34]without secretarial help.

[08:21.51]ordered, signed or asked about something often is crucial.

[08:50.67]is not overdone,
